content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a cross-section of a colorectal resection. There is a large, exophytic, and ulcerated tumor mass that appears to be arising from the mucosa. The bulk of the tumor is intensely basophilic, suggesting high cellularity. In the bottom right corner, there is a separate, well-circumscribed, ovoid structure with a basophilic cortex and lighter medulla, which is characteristic of a lymph node. My initial task would be to assess the primary tumor for depth of invasion (T stage) and to examine the separate lymph node for metastasis (N stage).
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this specific area of the primary tumor to assess its histological features. This location is within the main body of the tumor and appears representative of its architecture. The purpose is to confirm the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, evaluate its differentiation (how well it forms glands), and assess the cytologic atypia (irregularity of the nuclei, mitotic activity). This detailed examination is crucial for grading the tumor and understanding its morphology before I proceed to find the deepest point of invasion into the bowel wall to determine the T stage. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see infiltrating, crowded, and irregularly shaped glands. The neoplastic cells forming these glands exhibit significant atypia, characterized by enlarged, hyperchromatic, and elongated (pencil-shaped) nuclei that are pseudostratified. There is a loss of normal crypt architecture. The stroma between the glands appears desmoplastic. These features are characteristic of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma. The glandular formation is still apparent, but it is highly disorganized and infiltrative.
